channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Customs' Covid-19 request for crew arriving in Port Taranaki labelled discrimination
item.description: Customs is asking that the crew of overseas vessels carry evidence they've completed Covid-19 protocols and have health authority permission when they take shore leave.

item.title: Tourism industry hopeful after plans for trans-Tasman travel bubble announced
item.description: There's been a boost in confidence for tourism operators, as Cabinet agrees in principle to establish a travel bubble with Australia in the first quarter of 2021.

item.title: Prison officers' union rejects chief ombudsman's scathing report
item.description: The union for prison officers is rejecting a report pointing to the cruel treatment of inmates and people being locked in their cells for up to 23 hours at a time.

item.title: How our eating habits changed in lockdown
item.description: The Detail - The stresses of lockdown pushed many to reach for junk food and alcohol and a nutrition expert warns the effect on people's lives will last much longer.

item.title: Lack of funding, burnout contributes to urgent care clinic halting overnight service
item.description: A lack of funding, high demand and staff burnout are part of why East Care in South Auckland is stopping its overnight service.

item.title: Gasfitter to be sentenced over explosion in Christchurch house
item.description: The explosion - in house in Christchurch last July - completely destroyed the home and injured six people.

item.title: Oranga Tamariki deputy head Hoani Lambert has resigned, chief executive confirms
item.description: Grainne Moss has confirmed Oranga Tamariki deputy chief executive Hoani Lambert has resigned, but she herself is not stepping down.

item.title: Chief Ombudsman's unannounced visit of Paremoremo prison reveals failures
item.description: A report into the country's only maximum security prison reveals myriad problems and shows it is failing on promises to boost rehabilitation.

item.title: Salter scales taken in 1950s from Discovery Hut in Antarctic now returned
item.description: The return of a historic set of scales souvenired from an English explorer's base hut more than 60 years ago is being celebrated by Antarctic Heritage Trust.

item.title: Baby's death: Waikato DHB says sorry after uterus ruptured
item.description: The Waikato District Health Board has apologised to a woman for failings in her care after her uterus ruptured, and her child died a month later.

item.title: Central Auckland residents not put off but concerned by recent gun violence
item.description: Despite another incident at a bar involving a gun - the third within a month - a residents' group say people are not dissuaded about going out in the CBD.

item.title: State home openings in Porirua a welcome start while hundreds remain in motels
item.description: The opening of dozens of new state homes in Porirua is being described as an important milestone but hundreds of people remain in cramped temporary housing.

item.title: Car dealer fined $67k for breaching consumer rights
item.description: The used car dealer had been selling low-priced used vehicles on an 'as-is-where-as' basis with no warranty, and failing to provide required information.

item.title: Dangerous Invercargill intersection to get $5m roundabout
item.description: There have been 20 crashes in the past decade at the Elles Road/SH1 roundabout in south Invercargill.

item.title: Scorching weather prompts restricted fire season in Canterbury
item.description: A restricted fire season has been declared for the whole of Canterbury ahead of scorching weather predicted for later this week.

item.title: First court appearance over Whakaari eruption, case adjourned until March
item.description: The first court appearance for the 13 parties facing charges over alleged health and safety breaches in the lead-up to last year's Whakaari eruption has been adjourned.

item.title: Otago University postpones graduation events for the week
item.description: The University of Otago is postponing all of this week's graduation ceremonies and parades following a security threat last week.

item.title: Scott Watson parole was rejected over lack of psychological treatment - board
item.description: Convicted murderer Scott Watson had made little progress in identifying appropriate treatment arising from risk factors identified four years ago, the Parole Board says.
